title: 106_s2367
content:
The Act is titled the "Travel, Tourism, and Jobs Preservation Act." It eliminates pilot program status in Title I. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to remove references to a pilot program, making changes to various subsections. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to remove references to a pilot program in various subsections. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to remove references to a pilot program in various subsections, including subsection (f) and section 212(a)(7)(B)(iv). TITLE II--PROGRAM IMPROVEMENTS

SEC. 201. EXTENSION OF RECIPROCAL PRIVILEGES.

Amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to extend reciprocal privileges with designated countries for immigration admissions.

SEC. 202. MACHINE READABLE PASSPORT PROGRAM. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act requires aliens to possess a valid machine-readable passport for admission, effective October 1, 2008. Additionally, reciprocal privileges for immigration admissions with designated countries are extended. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require countries to issue machine-readable passports that meet international standards. Countries designated before May 1, 2000, must certify compliance by October 1, 2001. The Immigration and Nationality Act amended to require countries to issue machine-readable passports meeting international standards by October 1, 2003. SEC. 203 requires an evaluation of the impact of a country's participation on law enforcement and national security. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State, evaluates the impact of a country's designation on law enforcement and national security interests of the United States. This includes the enforcement of immigration laws, ensuring that such interests would not be compromised by the designation. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State, periodically evaluates the effect of each program country's continued designation on law enforcement and national security interests, submitting written reports to the Committee on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives and Senate every 5 years. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State, evaluates the impact of each program country's designation on US law enforcement and national security interests every 5 years. A written report is submitted to the Committee on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives and Senate regarding the continuation or rescission of the country's designation. The Attorney General evaluates the impact of each program country's designation on US law enforcement and national security interests every 5 years. A written report is submitted to the Committee on the Judiciary of the United States House of Representatives and Senate regarding the continuation or rescission of the country's designation, with effects described in clause (i).
